ParentCompanyName: Los Angles Department of Water and Power

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chlorine is the most commonly used substance for disinfecting drinking water.  The addition of chlorine or chlorine compounds to water is called chlorination.  Chlorination is considered to be the most important process for preventing the spread of waterborne disease in drinking water.  The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power (LADWP) also uses chlorine for drinking water disinfection purposes to protect public health per state and federal water quality standards.  Storing and handling large quantities of chlorine can create hazardous situations.  LADWP takes safety obligations in storing and using chlorine as seriously as it takes providing safe drinking water.  LADWP has been operating the Encino Chlorination Station (ECS) since 1956, which is a chlorination facility that stores and uses anhydrous chlorine for disinfection purposes.  LADWP decided to make significant changes to the existing chlorination facility to further enhance the safety and offsite consequences of an accidental chlorine release. The modified chlorination facility is in operation since 2006. The modified Encino chlorination station chlorine handling process is also subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program and Plan, and also to the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program regulations.  EPA and CalARP regulations require the preparation and five year update of the Risk Management Plan for facilities subject to federal EPA and CalARP regulations. An update is required at least once every five years from the date of its initial submission.  An update is also required within six months of a change that alters the Program Level that applied to any covered process.

The RMP is to include policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility and the actions which will be taken by the facility in an event of an emergency. A Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Encino Chlorination Station was prepared in June 1999 that was updated in

June 2004.  The Risk Management Plan and Program for the modified chlorination facility was prepared in April 2006.  Subsequent to the preparation of the Risk Management Program in April 2006, a few minor changes in the piping system were made.  An update to the April 2006 Risk Management Plan, reflecting these minor changes was prepared in December 2006.  LADWP prepared Program Level 2 RMPs from 1999 through 2006 because Encino Chlorination Station is not subject to PSM regulations. However, in the excess of caution, LADWP has now decided to prepare a Program Level 3 RMP for the Encino facility. Thus, this 2010 update of the Risk Management Plan for the Encino facility demonstrates compliance with the Program Level 3 requirements.  It should be noted that no changes have been made to the Encino Chlorination Station after the preparation of the December 2006 Risk Management Plan.

The following information is specifically required in the RMP Executive Summary: 

A?    Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
A?    General facility and regulated substances information.
A?    Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.
A?    Five-year accident history summary.
A?    Emergency response program summary.
A?    Planned changes to improve safety.

The above information for the Encino chlorination station is provided below.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The LADWP accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates the use of proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable requirements of the State of California and EPAA?s Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.  

The LADWP emergency response policy involves the preparation of emergency response plans for hazardous materials

which are tailored to each facility and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with the EPA and CalARP Program Emergency Response Program Requirements.  The LADWP has prepared an Emergency Response Plan for the Encino Chlorination Station to facilitate coordination and emergency planning with offsite response officials and facilities in the event of an emergency.  The emergency response plan has been coordinated with local response agencies (City of Los Angeles Fire Department).  The Encino Chlorination Station has a good record in preventing accidents from occurring. 

General Facility and Regulated Substance Information

The Encino Chlorination Station is located at 4500 Encino Avenue, Encino, California.  The station serves to disinfect drinking water by chlorinating water in the reservoir and at various locations in the on-site water piping system.  The treated water is then piped into the distribution network, which serves parts of the San Fernando Valley with potable water.  The station consists of a three building complex: the pump station, the chlorination station and the membrane filtration plant. The facility stores chlorine, a regulated toxic substance under the EPA and CalARP Program rules. Chlorine containers can be attached to the liquid chlorine header for discharging chlorine, as well as to the gas header which provides an automatic backup supply. The maximum quantity of chlorine present at the Encino chlorination station at any given time exceeds the listed threshold quantities in the EPA and CalARP rules.  It also exceeds the listed threshold quantities in the federal and California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standards.  However, the facility is normally unmanned and water treatment operators visit the facility daily and respond to any trouble alarms, which may occur.  Thus, the LADWP Encino facility is not subject to federal or California OSHA PS

M regulations.

During normal operations, chlorine containers are manifolded together in two banks to supply chlorine, while others are stored as spares.  On-line containers rest on load cell scales, which allow the operators to monitor the chlorine weight remaining in each container. All on-line containers are equipped with automatic closure actuators on the container valves. The primary bank is connected to the chlorine liquid header and the secondary bank is connected to the chlorine gas header.  The liquid chlorine passes from the containers to the evaporator where it is vaporized in a water bath.  Gas from the secondary bank of containers bypasses the evaporators, serving as an automatic backup when the primary containers run dry, or when the evaporators shut down due to (1) a low water level, (2) low temperature condition, or (3) power loss.  Space is allocated in the room for the storage of additional chlorine containers without any connection to the chlorination system.

The gas header line is equipped with automatic switchover vacuum regulating valves, and pressure gauges.  The liquid header line is equipped with pressure gauges and an expansion chamber to protect against excessive pressure.  The primary (liquid) bank provides all the chlorine to the station through the evaporators until it is depleted.  The gaseous chlorine bank automatically starts supplying chlorine when the primary bank is depleted.  This automatic system is achieved by setting the automatic vacuum regulating valve leading from the secondary bank to standby.  Once the primary bank is depleted, the higher vacuum level acts on the diaphragm of the automatic switchover vacuum regulating in the secondary bank, thereby pulling that valve open to start feeding gas.

The gaseous chlorine from the evaporators or from the chlorine gas header proceeds to the chlorinators that regulate the flow of chlorine.  Chlorine gas from the chlorinators is pulled by vacuum to injectors located in an undergro

und vault, cabinet, or within the membrane filtration building.  The injectors provide vacuum, which draws chlorine gas into mixing water to form a concentrated solution.  The solution is then piped through diffusers into the reservoir and to various locations in the on-site water piping system.

A dry media type chlorine gas scrubber system is installed at the station.  The unit is actuated by chlorine detectors at a chlorine concentration of 3 ppm.  The scrubber is provided to neutralize an accidental release of chlorine gas from the chlorine storage or chlorinator rooms.  The scrubber draws suction from the chlorine storage and chlorinator rooms through a duct.  The station is equipped with uninterruptible power supply (UPS) in addition to a backup power generator.  Therefore, in case of the failure of regular power, the scrubber will be functional.

Chlorine leak sensors are provided to detect chlorine leaks in the chlorine storage room, the chlorinator room and the chlorine scrubber room.  The detectors activate an alarm system which includes:  (1) flashing red lights over the entry door to the building, (2) audible and flashing alarms within the chlorination building, and (3) an alarm at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) at Sylmar.  Also, the chlorine injector vaults are equipped with chlorine leak sensors.

Process control is by a programmable controller, which determines the feed rate relative to the water flow rate.  There are flow meters transmitting flow signals to the controller.  Chlorine residual analyzers continuously monitor and record the treated water residuals.

In the event power is lost at the chlorination facility, an alarm will alert the LAAFP control room.  Chlorine flow will continue unaffected, with no safety consequences.  An emergency generator will automatically start and supply power to the entire system.

The facility is normally unmanned; water treatment operators visit the facility daily. A response team coordinated f

rom LADWP Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) responds to any trouble alarms, which may occur.  Access to the facility is through gates, which are kept locked all the time.

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The LADWP accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

A?    Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
A?    Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
A?    Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
A?    Performance of process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.
A?    Use of industry recommended process and safety equipment.
A?    Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operators.
A?    High level of training of the operators and maintenance staff.
A?    Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.

Chemical-specific prevention steps include availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine supply, awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine, presence of chlorine detectors with remote monitoring, the use of automatic closure actuators on the on-line chlorine container valves, a chlorine main scrubber, and a chlorine mini-scrubber (currently not in operation).

Process and Chemical Safety Information

Comprehensive chemical data has been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine.  This information includes chlorine background information and MSDS sheets.

Equipment safety information was compiled on the chlorine process. Specifications for the chlorine process are collected and

provided in one place for easy reference. Details such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; and safe upper and lower pressures for the chlorination facility are on file at the facility.  LADWP also has procedures in place that are triggered to update process safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.

Process Hazard Analysis/Hazard Review

On October 13, 2006, a hazard review/process hazard analysis was conducted for the modified chlorination system equipment and procedures.  The process hazard analysis review will be updated again within a five-year period or whenever there is major change in the process. A list of recommended actions was developed in October 2006 to further improve the chlorine safety.  All recommendations have been evaluated and implemented by LADWP staff.

A seismic walkthrough was completed on August 23, 2005 based on the LEPC Region 1 guidance document, and recommendations were provided to LADWP staff for their evaluation and implementation.  These recommendations have been evaluated and implemented.  The recommendations involved providing additional seismic hold-down chains and brackets for the chlorine containers that had not yet been installed after the piping system modifications.

Operating Procedures

LADWP has prepared written operating procedures for Encino chlorination facility that provide clear instructions or steps for safely conducting activities relating to chlorination process. They are consistent with the chlorine safety information. Written operating procedures included in the facilityA?s Operation and Maintenance Manual include:

A?    Delivery of Chlorine
A?    Container Connections 
A?    Initial Startup Procedure 
A?    Normal Operation 
A?    Normal Shutdown 
A?    Temporary Operations 
A?    Emergency Operations 
A?    Emergency Shutdown 
A?    Startup Following Emergency Shutdown 

Training 

The LADWP ensures that each employee operating or maintaining the chlorination p

rocess, and each employee newly assigned to this process, is trained and tested for competency in the operating procedures listed above. The LADWP employee training documentation files include training records for each employee assigned to operate or maintain the chlorination process.  The training ensures that the employee has the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities, including chlorine emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures.  Employee training includes as a minimum the following elements:

A?    Safety Information.
A?    Process Technology and Process Equipment, including safety systems.
A?    Maintenance Procedures.
A?    Operating Procedures for the chlorine system.
A?    RMP Program contents.
A?    Emergency Response Plan and Procedures.

Refresher training is provided at least every three years to each employee operating the chlorination process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  In addition, LADWP ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after major modifications.  Training programs for the Encino Chlorination Station were most recently reviewed on August 4, 2009.

Contractors

LADWP Contractor procedures specify the information required to be provided to the contractors performing work on or near the chlorination process, the training requirements for contractor employees, and mechanism to obtain assurance from contractors that they have informed their employees of the appropriate safety rules.  LADWP provides information and explanations concerning the hazards and processes. 

Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program

LADWP has procedures in place to ensure that a pre-startup safety review is conducted prior to starting a new covered process or prior to making modifications to the chlorination systems that require a MOC procedure implementation.  The required conditions

prior to startup include:

A?    Construction and/or equipment are in accordance with design specifications.
A?    Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate.
A?    A PHA has been performed for any new facilities and recommendations have been resolved or implemented prior to startup.
A?    At modified facilities, MOC requirements have been met.
A?    Training of each operating and maintenance employee involved in the process is complete.

These procedures ensure that no new/significantly modified process will start-up and no regulated substances will be introduced into such a process prior to the pre-startup safety review.  This constitutes a final check that the process and equipment are ready to go and that the recommendations of the PHA have been implemented or adequately addressed.  This will ensure that the design and construction of a new or modified process is safely executed and that the facility is prepared to operate it. 

Mechanical integrity procedures for the plant ensure that written maintenance procedures are implemented and documented, including training of maintenance personnel.

Maintenance 

The LADWP operates a computerized maintenance management program that generates a task order for performance of the preventive maintenance routine at pre-determined intervals based on the type of equipment.  Description of the work to be performed is included with the printed work order.  The water treatment supervisor is responsible for this task.  

In addition, the written maintenance procedure is provided in the Operation and Maintenance Manual as follows: Preventive maintenance schedules are provided which summarize inspection, test, and maintenance schedules on a daily, weekly, bi-monthly, monthly, biannual, annual, every 2 to 10 years, and as-needed basis.  These allow the operator to rapidly review what maintenance is necessary.  The schedules are supplemental to the log sheets on-site and provide a summary and quick refere

nce to manufacturer's O&M manuals.  A maintenance log book is provided on-site for quick reference by the Operator. 
LADWP documents inspection, testing, and maintenance of chlorination equipment and assures the performance is done in accordance with the recommendations of the manufacturer and industry groups (i.e., Chlorine Institute).

Hot Work Permits and Management of Change 

Hot work refers to work involving electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing, or similar flame or spark producing operations.  The procedures call for the issuance of a hot work permit whenever it is conducted on or near the chlorination process and other areas deemed appropriate as described in the procedures.  Fire prevention and protection systems are in place prior to the issuance of the hot work permit.  The permit indicates the dates the work is authorized for, the location and specific operational requirements and is kept on file in the administrative office. 

LADWP Management of Change (MOC) procedures include steps required to be taken by plant personnel prior to implementing changes to chlorination equipment, procedures, raw materials, and processing conditions.  Training, PSI, operating procedures, and maintenance procedures are updated according to the changes made.

Internal Compliance Audits

The LADWP has been certifying at a minimum of every three years that compliance with 
Program 2 Prevention Program requirements is met and that procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed. Starting April 2010, compliance audits will seek to verify compliance with Program 3 Prevention Program requirements. 

The compliance audit consists of separating the RMP program elements or sections, and auditing each element to determine compliance and effectiveness.  For each internal audit, the audit team completes a Compliance Audit Certification Page and Compliance Audit Checklist forms (one form for each preventive program requirement).  The Compliance Audit Certification

Page provides process identification, the dates of the audit, team members, and certification by the audit leader.  The Compliance Audit Checklist details the requirements of each RMP element and contains questions that may assist with the auditing process. The audit checklist for each element consists of the following three sections:

A?    Records Review: A review of the RMP written Prevention Program.
A?    On-Site Conditions: The audit team will review the program elements based on observation of the plant conditions and safety practices.
A?    Interviews:  The program elements will be evaluated by interviewing personnel from appropriate functions including operations, maintenance, management, and contractors.
Team members record RMP program deficiencies identified during the audit on the checklist.

Incident Investigation

The LADWP incident investigation procedures describe incident reporting, investigation, and investigation reporting steps to be followed by plant personnel.  The incident investigation is started promptly but no later than 48 hours after the event.  The LADWP promptly addresses and resolves all recommendations and shall implement the recommendations in a timely manner to prevent an incident recurrence.  All incident investigation reports are retained on LADWP file for at least a period of five years from the date the reports are completed.

Five-year Accident History Summary

No chlorine releases that could have caused safety or health hazard (deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage evacuations, or sheltering in place) occurred at the Encino Chlorination Station during the last five years.

Emergency Response Program Summary

LADWP is a first responder, its employees respond to chlorine accidental releases.  In the event an accidental release that could result in offsite consequences occurs, external resources such as the City of Los Angeles Fire Department will be solicited to respond as well.  

As part of the emergency response program,

the LADWP has developed and implemented an emergency response plan for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment.  
The following elements are included:

(a)    An emergency response plan, maintained at the stationary source and at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) containing:
A?    Organizational structure (chain-of-command) and responsibilities of various LADWP personnel.
A?    Procedures for planning and coordination with off-site emergency response organizations.
A?    Details of the training programs for all employees involved with the chlorination process, contractor training, and medical surveillance of LADWP personnel who respond to chlorine releases.
A?    Details of emergency recognition and prevention at the LADWP.
A?    Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases.
A?    Documentation of proper first aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures and the detailed information on emergency health care.
A?    Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release.
(b)    Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection, testing, and maintenance. 
(c)    Training in relevant procedures for all employees involved with the chlorination process.
(d)    Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes and ensure that employees are informed of changes.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

As part of updating the Risk Management Program for the Encino chlorination station, a hazard review/process hazard analysis of the modified chlorination system was performed on October 13, 2006.  The hazard review/process hazard analysis was performed using the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) technique and covered equipment and main procedures used for the chlorination process.  All the recommendations made based on the process hazard analysis have been evaluated and implemented.
